captions.text:
You and me? We've got some
stuff in common.

More in common than, say, you and
my dogs Lemon and Abby here.

For starters, you and I are
probably the same species.

And Lemon and Abby are dogs,
which is a different species.

As you may have guessed by now,
this video is going to

be about species!
But at the very end,

we're going to talk about dogs.
So hang in there,
because the puppies are coming.

Before we bust out the puppies,
let's talk about people.

Our species, Homo Sapiens, is the
single remaining member of
the genus Homo.

Our buddies Homo Erectus
and Homo Habilis
and Homo Neanderthalensis

bought the farm a long time ago.
So these days, all us Homo sapiens

are pretty different from even our
closest living relatives in the

animal Kingdom,
the chimps and bonobos.

Humans are a species, a specific
type of organism that's different

from all the other types
of organisms out there.

But what is it that makes us human?
Well, we're a specific type of
animal called a primate.

Monkeys, apes, lemurs,
and tarsiers are also primates.

Unless you're Sacha Baron Cohen
or something, most of us are
lacking significant body hair.

We're bipedal, meaning we stand
on two feet, and we've got these

huge-normous brains, that allow us
to do all kinds of stuff like

talk real good,
solve complicated problems,

write bad poetry during
adolescence, and figure out how

little we can get away with
tipping a mediocre waiter at a

restaurant without seeming
like a total prick.

THAT, my friends, is something
that giraffes rarely have
to deal with.

But being a species is more than
having a bunch of stuff in common.

Instead we describe a species as
a group of organisms that can

interbreed and produce
fertile offspring.

Seems pretty simple, right?
Two of the same species that
can produce blah blah blah...

HEY! Pay attention! That last part
is important! The two organisms

need to be able to
produce fertile offspring.

It seems like it would be enough
for organisms of the same species

to be able to make babies,
but those babies need to
be able to make babies, too.

Now it turns out, two animals of a
different species can sometimes

technically have a baby.
Take, for instance,

the noble liger, Napoleon
Dynamite's favorite animal,

which I know because I had the very
best Napoleon Dynamite costume in

the United States for
Halloween in 2005.

But, I didn't just bring
ligers up to brag.

A liger is what happens when a
male lion and a female tiger
have a little cub.

Only, it's not very little because
a liger is generally larger than

both of its parents.
And ligers are sterile.

Which leads us to our understanding
of what makes a species: lions and

tigers are different species
because they don't produce
fertile offspring together.

We call animals like ligers
hybrids, the offspring resulting

from the cross-breeding of
two distinct species.

And even though hybridization
between two animals is a dead end

when it comes to creating
a new species, we know that

through evolution, or the change
in the heritable characteristics

of a species across generations,
new species have formed

in the past, and they continue
to develop all the time.

It's tough to nail down every
single way this process we call

speciation can happen, but we know
of at least a couple ways that

species evolve into other species.
And they both involve

one requirement: reproductive
isolation, meaning two populations

of the same species can no
longer mate together successfully.

Note that I said successfully.
One way populations can become

isolated from each other is that
they can mate, but their offspring

aren't fertile or viable.
Ligers are a good example of this.

So are mules, they're the product
of a male donkey and

a female horse.
Unlike lions and tigers,

donkeys and horses don't even have
the same number of chromosomes,

so even though the donkey sperm
can fertilize the horse egg,

the mule won't have the genetic
instructions it needs to produce
its own sex cells.

This kind of isolation is call
post-zygotic, because the parents

can form a zygote together,
but after that it's all
over for their lineage.

Other examples of post-zygotic
isolation include pairings of

species that always lead to
miscarriage or no development

of the embryo at all,
or things like big fetuses
that kill the mother at birth.

The other type of isolation is
pre-zygotic, meaning the isolation

happened between groups of the
same species before an egg even

thought about getting fertilized.
This can include stuff like

behavioral changes within a
species, like when birds of the

same species start singing two
different songs to attract mates.

Or when one group of a species
that does all its business in the

daytime gradually becomes
nocturnal, so the two groups

never end up hanging
out at the same time.

Pre-zygotic isolation
can also be geographic,

meaning simply that the
populations are separated

by great distances
or physical barriers,

so that they can no longer
get together to bump uglies.

When one species diverges into
two new species because

of geographic isolation,
it's called allopatric speciation,

allopatric coming from the
Greek for "different countries."

The two populations of a species
end up evolving differently

because conditions are different
on each side of this river here.

It might be colder on one
side of the river,

so the animals on this
side grow thicker,

more luxurious coats because those
guys just do better over there.

They probably also put on
thicker layers of fat,

and change their behavior,
and accumulate a bunch

of other possibly random changes.
Meanwhile, on the warm side

of the river, these animals also
accumulate changes, and lose some

fur and add a bunch of
sweat glands. Given enough time,

and given a complete lack of gene
flow between the two populations,

thick-coated animals will
eventually only be able to breed
with other thick-coated animals,

and sweaty animals
with sweaty animals.

This propagation of specific
traits based on how kick-ass

those traits make the animal that
has them is called

natural selection. And a guy named
Charles Darwin or Chuck Darwin,
or Chucky D to his friends...

was the one who let us know what
was up with natural selection

and how it can lead
to allopatric speciation.

Stop me if you've heard this one
before, but Darwin visited the

Galapagos Islands in the 1830s.
So Darwin was obsessed

with barnacles, but that didn't
keep him from noticing the finches,

which were actually misidentified
by him as grosbeaks,

on each island were all pretty
similar to the finches on the

other islands AND very similar to
the ones on the mainland of

South America BUT they were also
obviously their own species.

Darwin believed that the process
that led to these finches becoming

separate species was incredibly
slow, so slow that we couldn't

actually witness the process,
we just had to take his word for it.

Now, for a long time after Darwin
made these observations,

allopatric speciation was the main
explanation for how species diverge.

But today we know that's not the
whole truth. Now, we've got lots

of new-fangled DNA testing and
other special gadgetry that tells

us that one species can diverge
into two without being

geographically separated,
but instead, when they're

reproductively isolated in some
other way. This is called

sympatric speciation, meaning
"same country," and it also means

that it's time for a
trip to the chair!

So, here's a little biological
love story for all you

romantics out there.
Peter and Rosemary Grant,

two British evolutionary biologists
(they are, in fact, a married couple)

have, since the early 1970s,
been spending 6 months of each

year together on a secluded
island in the Galapagos

studying Darwin's finches,
trying to catch them in the

act of evolving. These are,
mind you, the same animals

that Darwin studied,
and the ones that he

said were evolving at
an imperceptibly slow pace.

The island in the Galapagos
that the Grants hang out on

is called Daphne Major, and when
they started their research in 1973,

it was occupied by two
different finch species:

the medium ground finch
and the cactus finch.

But in 1981, another finch
arrived on Daphne Major

from a nearby island. It was a
ground finch-cactus finch hybrid,

and it was a whole lot bigger than
either of the local finches.

Its beak was also extra wide,
and its song was like a mashup

of the jams ground finches sang
on its home island and the ones

sung on Daphne Major. The newcomer
set to work crooning to the local

ground finch ladies,
and eventually landed one.

The Grants followed the
descendants of these two
birds for the next 28 years.

But after about 4 generations,
Daphne Major experienced a

severe drought which killed
many of the finches.

There were only TWO surviving
descendants of that one

immigrant finch, sort of like
cousins of each other, basically

and they mated with each other,
and that seems to have set the

stage for speciation to occur.
The descendants of these two

survivors sang a very distinctive
song that was learned from their

parents and which was
different from the other
Daphne Major finches.

Gradually as the finch population
on the island rebounded,
the hybrid finches, the great-great-
great-great-great grandchicks

of that one bird, began mating
exclusively with each other.

In December 2009, the Grants
announced that, since the drought,

the lineage of that one immigrant
ground finch has been genetically

isolated from the other
local finches on the island.

So, that, my friends, is both
super romantic and also an

example of super-quick
sympatric speciation in action.

Okay, so I promised you puppies,
so I'm gonna give you puppies.

You've probably noticed that,
you know, a corgi looks pretty

different from a greyhound.
They were bred to be different.

Corgis were bred to herd animals
and guard farm houses,

while greyhounds were bred
mostly to run.

Dog breeding kind of takes the
"natural" out of natural selection,

in fact, it's what we call
artificial selection,
but it's still a kind of selection.

You've probably wondered what it
would be like if a corgi and a

greyhound had puppies together?
Because they CAN

have puppies together.
Even though that's really weird.

What's that, Lemon?
You're both girls?
Oh, well- anyways..

My point here is that they're the
same species, meaning that

these dogs, even differenter dogs,
like an Irish wolfhound

and a chihuahua, could have
fertile offspring together.

Like, how? How... How?
Would- HOW!?

Various dog breeds are similar
enough that post-zygotic

isolation isn't an issue.
But in a natural setting,

a chihuahua-wolfhound pairing
would be extremely rare

because of the difficulties
involved in the

gettin' it on process.
Or "pre-zygotic obstacles."

So, think about it like this,
if you were to put a bunch of

chihuahuas and a bunch of
wolfhounds on an island somewhere

they probably wouldn't breed
together and if they did,

the birthing process, at least for
the chihuahua mommies would be...
Gah!
Oh god.

But what this means is that the
gene flow between the two groups

would stop, and they would
become reproductively isolated.

Over time, they could become
different enough that they could

no longer successfully breed
together at all, and thus become
different species.

Thank you for watching this episode
of Crash Course. If you missed

anything don't forget to go back
and review. If you have any

questions, please ask them in the
comments or of Facebook or Twitter.

We will endeavor to answer them.
Thank you to everyone who helped

put this episode together.
We'll see you next time.

comments.author: Joshua Holbrook

comments.text:
+Joshua Holbrook When a pair mate, their chromosomes are chopped up and 
switched around at random points on the chromosomes. This is called genetic 
shuffling (see 
http://evolution.berkeley.edu/evosite/evo101/IIIC5aShufflingdetails.shtml). 
This shuffling requires that the genes be highly the same structurally 
between the two individuals; if they aren't, genes can be functionally 
broken, causing a dead foetus. I have seen it estimated that about 1/3 of 
all human matings die before the fertilized egg even implants for this 
reason.


Fortunately, most mutations are harmless or possibly even helpful. Those 
that are deletory kill the result. The branches of sapiens and neanderthals 
were both still very compatible, enough so that they could successfully 
interbreed generally. That is all that need be said.

comments.text: does speciation always involve incest﻿
comments.author: geckoisred

comments.text:
+geckoisred Life requires it. Consider: if a human generation takes 20 
years, then 200 years ago everyone had 1000 ancestors. 400 years back, 
1,000,000 ancestors. At about 600 years, either everyone is sharing 
everyone else's ancestors, or some form of incest is taking place; there 
simply weren't enough people to have a billion ancestors 600 years ago. So 
people have ancestors showing up multiple times in their ancestoral tree.


As a corollary, you may have a snooty neighbor who brags about having 
Julius Caesar in his ancestry. All that is needful is to reflect that it 
will be a rare person living today who hasn't.

comments.text:
Within the chromasonal DNA information of a lion is the tiger's stripes. 
The tiger stripes is extremely recessive in the lion, but it is there. You 
put several generations of lions in tiger natural environment then the 
stripes will become less recessive and would become dominant. All the 
genetic traits existing amongst all of the species within a given genus are 
in the DNA information of all the species, but vary in range from extremely 
recessive to extremely dominant. And the zebra stripes are existant in the 
chromasonal DNA of draught horses and shetland ponies, for example, but 
these genetic traits are extremely recessive in such species. So that it 
would be extremely difficult to render the zebra stripes as outwardly 
evident in draught horses and shetland ponies, without cross-breeding them 
with zebras, or raising them in specifically zebra-like environmental 
conditions over many generations.﻿

comments.author: Doc Hudson

comments.text:
+Doc Hudson On the micro-biological level, the horse set of genes and the 
donkey set of genes are slowly mutating. Interbreeding tends to smooth out 
the differences, making members of the same species continuously 
interfertile, but the genetic track is still moving, and for the groups who 
only rarely interbreed, the differences pile up until genetic 
incompatibility first kills the ability to breed, and then kills all 
attempts at interbreeding (and "kill" is the term, as in dead embryos; 
nature loves a good abortion). Horses and donkeys seems to rather close to 
the cusp; a little more time and mules will disappear as a possibility. 
Probably something on the order of tens of thousands of years, barring 
human intervention.

comments.author: Edmond Rieffer

comments.text:
+Edmond Rieffer Theoretically, yes. The requirement for a complete 
speciation event is that there be only insignificant genetic exchange 
between the two groups and that it go on for long enough that genetic 
incompatibility closes off the chance of viable crosses being brought to 
breeding age. That time is generally thought of as ranging from tens to 
hundreds of thousands of years, sometimes millions.

comments.author: Edmond Rieffer

comments.text:
that is not the goal at all, and in coming decades as space travel becomes 
cheaper and more efficient it is entirely possible that less intelligent 
individuals could immigrate to Mars. Of course humans whose families 
settled on Mars would eventually be somewhat different from Earth humans 
due to the lower gravity and different environment, but they would still be 
humans and could have children with Earth humans. However, if a group of 
human colonists immigrated to a different world in another solar system, 
they would eventually evolve into a unique species since constant contact 
with other human settlements would be impossible (unless we develop warp 
drives or something, in which case the colony would have to cut off 
relations with other settlements completely for a long time to become a 
different species).

comments.text:
+andytallman101 No. Speciation happens to groups of beings, not 
individuals. A group will speciate from another when the interbreeding 
essentially stops, whatever the reason. Eventually, as a result, they will 
cease to be interfertile, making the speciation event complete.


There are long been a controversy as to whether Neanderthals were Homo 
neanderthalensis, or Homo sapiens neanderthalensis. The latter appears now 
to be the case: they are a variety of H. sap, and were not a separate 
species, just as dachshunds are a variety of gray wolf.


Here is the kicker: speciation and the concept of species are invented by 
man. Nature doesn't know or care, and man can only use the definition in a 
provisional, non-absolutist (sometime excessively so) way. That is science 
for you, ambiguity is often an integral part of the game. Be aware.

comments.text:
"This doesn't prove that 1 species can evolve into a completely different 
kind of animal."

Evolution does not permit organisms to change into "completely different 
'kinds' of animals". This is based on a fundamental misunderstanding of 
evolution but ultimately taxonomy as well. Besides the fact that you used 
terms with no scientific definition, I'll do my best to explain this. First 
off, "kind" refers to nothing. It is not a scientific term, it is not clear 
what this term describes, and it therefore should not be used in this 
context. Nevertheless, organisms never evolve out of their respective taxa. 
A tiger is a feliforme, but neither its ancestors nor its descendants have 
stopped or will stop being mammals. In other words, every organism in the 
Tigers evolutionary lineage both past and future will never be a 
"completely different kind of animal". But again, we have undefined terms. 
What exactly is a "completely different kind of animals"? Even a Tiger and 
a Crocodile share characteristics.

"As you said, a chihuahua could still breed with a wolfhound(not that that 
would happen, but they COULD produce fertile offspring) so why is it that 
humans cannot breed with chimps or bonobos?"

The potential for two isolated populations to produce fertile offspring is 
determined by their chromosomal relationship and the recency of their 
divergence. Chihuahuas and wolfhounds share the same number of chromosomes 
and their divergence was relatively recently. While it is possible for two 
organisms from populations with varying pairs of chromosomes to produce the 
occasional fertile offspring (30 documented cases of fertile mules in the 
last few centuries), it is a rarity and is not the only determining factor 
nor the most important. African wild dogs, for instance, share 78 
chromosomes with wolves, domesticated dogs, coyotes, etc... but cannot 
interbreed with any. To your point, the simple fact is that we don't know 
if humans can interbreed with bonobos or chimps, nobody has ever really 
tried besides a deranged soviet scientist and it's not clear if his methods 
were concrete. What does it matter anyway? Just because we share an 
evolutionary relationship with these two species doesn't mean we must be 
capable of interbreeding.

"And as far as evolution happening at an imperceptibly slow pace, we should 
still be able to see evolution happening on a cellular level at least every 
20 years. But we don't."

Evolution is a system of population mechanics and inheritance. In what 
universe would a single gene spread throughout an entire population of 7 
billion people in one generation?

"That seems to make sense except that most mutations are harmful and build 
up over generations decreasing the functionality of the species"

The harmful mutations dont build up- they are HARMFUL. By the laws of 
natural selection, that means that the original, non-harmful form of the 
gene will outcompete the harmful version and it will cease to exist, save 
perhaps as a recessive allele somewhere in the genome. That why nearly 
every single genetic disease is recessive- because if someone is only a 
carrier of the gene, then it remains and may be passed on to offspring. 
Dominant genetic diseases are /extremely rare/, because dominant genes are 
always expressed, and so the animal will have the disease. Diseased animals 
either die, have very few offspring, or dont breed entirely.

comments.text:
To believe in something that heavily debated by some, certainly, but 
definitely not by the entire scientific community, especially the people 
who have dedicated their life to studying it and finding proof or 
counterproof, of which there is, if any, a tiny tiny tiny amount. There's 
several excellent proofs of evolution that we know about, my personal 
favorite is the speckled moths.

Now, there are two varieties of these moths- some have an allele (that's 
the term for two forms of the same gene) for dark colouring, and some for 
light. Before the industrial revolution, tree barks were light coloured and 
so the light coloured moths survived longest and had more offspring, 
outnumbering the dark coloured moths by a huge percentage because the dark 
coloured ones were more easily noticed by birds and so eaten.

When the industrial revolution started, all the trees started to get coated 
in soot, darkening their colour. Now it was the light coloured moths that 
were spotted more and so the population changed, with the moths with the 
allele for dark colouring surviving longer than their lighter coloured 
relatives.

After we started to change from coal to gas, the trees got lighter again 
and the balance swung back in favour of the light coloured moths. Remember, 
humans had no direct connection in this. They just changed the tree 
colours. That could have easily be done by a volcano spurting out clouds of 
ash, or a drought causing regular forest fires which darkened the trees 
with soot.

comments.text:
+CaveFreediving Alright. There is evidence that evolution is a thing. We 
have the fossil record which can be used to look at earlier species, the 
chemical composition of organisms (I'm going with organisms here because 
animals only applies to those organisms within kingdom Animalia, but does 
not include bacteria, protists, and the like) which can be compared to see 
how similar it is across species, homologous structures can be used to 
compare similarities and differences between species, geographic 
distributions of related species, and the recorded genetic change in 
organisms over a span of several generations. (source: 
http://anthro.palomar.edu/evolve/evolve_3.htm)
So speciation. First we need to define what a species is. There is still 
some debate over what exactly a species is, but the most accepted 
definition is: A group of actually or potentially interbreeding organisms 
whose offspring will produce fertile offspring. Pretty much the babies can 
make babies. Once speciation occurs the two species generally cannot 
reproduce together because of various barriers. The barriers may be that 
their genetic code is too different to go through mitosis and meiosis 
without serious problems, or they reproduce differently. For example, we 
(humans) cannot reproduce with robins because the reproduction methods are 
different. Humans have sexual intercourse which involves penetration while 
birds have sexual intercourse but with no penetration (the males actually 
give females sacks of sperm which the females place inside a canal of 
sorts). Since the reproduction methods are different, humans could not 
reproduce with birds. There's also the issue of size: Humans are much 
bigger than birds. Now, species can actually recombine into one species 
(which is a totally different form of speciation) and sometimes two species 
can create hybrids. Mostly the hybrids are sterile and very compromised in 
terms of health. To sum up species can't reproduce with each other because 
of behavioral differences, genetic differences, reproduction differences, 
parts don't match, or geographic isolation. Now, I do agree with you on the 
dog breeding example. It can't really be used to prove speciation, but it 
is a handy example of how variation can occur and how selection (in this 
case artificial selection) can happen.
We have actually observed evolution in action with fruit flies and 
organisms with sort generation periods. With fruit flies we can watch 
speciation happen because a generation period is relatively short and they 
produce lots of offspring. Since generation period is short we can observe 
a genetic change as it passes through the generations in a small period of 
time, say 10 generations in a week. That's enough time to see how the trait 
affects the adaption of the organism to the environment. This is, of 
course, an example of artificial selection.
The part of evolution that takes million of years is the change in whole 
kingdoms and the bigger classifications of organisms (domain, phylum, 
kingdom, class). Sometimes speciation takes million of years because of 
environmental conditions (environment refers to anything that affects the 
organisms. That is ecosystem, other organisms, weather patterns, food, etc) 
fluctuating quite a bit.
Scientists have lots of evidence of evolution. It may be called a theory, 
but in science a theory is when a hypothesis has enough evidence to be 
considered fact and thus other hypotheses are based off of it. Evolution is 
a scientific theory meaning that its scientific fact. It's is not, however, 
a scientific law. In order to be a law, we (scientists) must be able to 
predict that it will happen and then observe it happening. We have proof 
that verifies evolution, but we have no way of predicting when it may 
happen or how it will happen. This is unlike gravity where we can predict 
that if we drop a bowling ball from a certain height that it will hit the 
ground at a certain speed and time. Just because evolution is called a 
theory does not mean it is not fact. If it was a hypothesis it could be 
disproven. 
And scientists can't directly observe evolution, but we observe its 
affects. It's like wind. We can't directly observe it (with vision), but we 
can observe its affects upon the world and measure those affects.

+RodriguezSounds reptile and mammal aren't species identifiers. They're a

species. At least one of the groups can be said to have "changed species", 
because where there was one species name before, now there are two. Which 
one actually did is a moot point.

comments.text:
Look at the platypus. It has ten sex chromosomes and some of them actually 
are more like chickens chromosomes than mammals. Mammals have XY but birds 
and most reptiles have ZW. One of the X chromosomes has a gene that is on 
birds Z chromosomes. I am not saying that mammals evolved from a platypus, 
but the platypus is kind of what's left of mammals before they started 
giving birth to live young! Obviously, giving birth to live young proved to 
be more beneficial in mammals because the rest do it! So all the other 
mammals that use to lay eggs died out, but the platypus survived. Echidna 
evolved from platypus and also lay eggs. Then after that there are two 
types of mammals that give birth to live young, marsupials and placentals. 
Marsupials give birth to live young, but at a very early stage. So 
pregnancy is short, and the baby has to grow outside the womb. They 
developed in South America, but because Australia is now isolated they 
flourished there! From fossil records the birth canal is small on early 
mammals and so they probably gave birth like marsupials. Placental mammals, 
have a placenta and carry young for a long time before giving birth. 
Pregnancy is harder on than on marsupials, but considering the fact that 
most mammals do it this way, it is obviously beneficial to species 
survival! Mammals evolved from reptiles just like birds did. When the 
ruling reptiles (dinosaurs) fell, mammals and birds were able to rapidly 
take over and diverse. There were mammals before the end of the dinosaurs, 
but if the dinosaurs hadn't fallen they may not have amounted to much. Just 
like marsupials did better in Australia than in South America because they 
didn't have competition from placental mammals. So that is part of the 
reason why people can't see a reptile turning into a bird, or mammals. When 
there is already something filling the space or role, it's hard for a new 
thing to come in and take over. It's better when there is space that is 
open. And come on doesn't that whole process just seem awesome!
comments.author: Bernadette Emery

comments.text:
Yes it did evolve into another species.

Reptiles, mammals ... are not species but different classes in the

to keep in mind that evolution produces a tree, not a ladder.
comments.author: John Doe

comments.text:
Just isolate two sets of finches and give them a LONG time. Since they 
can't pass characteristics back and forth, they'll slowly grow more and 
more different until they can't produce fertile offspring--at which point 
they're considered different species. If you gave one of the species more 
time and did things like remove the pressure to fly, the finches might lose 
their wings and start to look more like reptiles (again, over many 
generations. Or if a lot of food was available in the water, the finches 
might start to learn to swim, eventually develop fins, and be thought of as 
fish. Again, none of this happens within an individual (you can't "learn" 
or "grow" fins yourself), but rather between each generation as mutations 
bring in new traits that are beneficial. 

Killerbee--Ken Ham has already won if scientists act condescendingly 
towards the curious.
